Localisation.report_string:
--- Localisation ---
Agree with lesions involving:
- left cerebellum and left optic nerve.
  
The suggested lesion bilateral length-dependent peripheral polyneuropathy not necessary to explain the signs.

Differential diagnosis.report_string:
--- Differential diagnosis ---
Correctly included Multiple sclerosis.

Other possible differentials:
- NMOSD (AQP4+), MOGAD, Neurosarcoid, SLE and Neurosyphilis.
- Also feasible but of low probability: Vasculitis, Susac Syndrome, Sjogren's, ADEM, Behçet's, Lymphoma and Lyme.

The following suggested diagnoses have a low probability of providing a unifying explanation for the full clinical presentation:
- Isolated left cerebellar infarct in the PICA or SCA territory (including vertebral artery dissection) (plausible for unilateral cerebellum; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Primary cerebellar tumour (e.g. low-grade astrocytoma) or cerebellar metastasis (plausible for unilateral cerebellum; but atypical for unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Autoimmune or post-infectious cerebellitis (atypical for strictly unilateral cerebellum and unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (atypical for strictly unilateral cerebellum and unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Diabetic length-dependent sensorimotor polyneuropathy (atypical for unilateral cerebellum and unilateral optic nerve involvement)
- Non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy of the left eye (plausible for unilateral optic nerve; but atypical for unilateral cerebellum involvement)

ft_diagnoses_raw: Isolated left cerebellar infarct in the PICA or SCA territory (including vertebral artery dissection)
Primary cerebellar tumour (e.g. low-grade astrocytoma) or cerebellar metastasis
Advanced proliferative diabetic retinopathy of the left eye
Non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy of the left eye
additional_diagnoses: Isolated left cerebellar infarct in the PICA or SCA territory (including vertebral artery dissection)
Primary cerebellar tumour (e.g. low-grade astrocytoma) or cerebellar metastasis
Advanced proliferative diabetic retinopathy of the left eye
Non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy of the left eye

Investigations.report_string:
--- Investigations ---

- Agree with the suggested MRI including the Brain and Orbits and CSF test for Oligoclonal Bands - would potentially inform a diagnosis/details of multiple sclerosis.

To evaluate other differential diagnoses:
- Agree with considering: anti-MOG, ANA, CRP, anti-AQP4, ESR.
- Could also consider testing: anti-dsDNA, ENA, ACE, ANCA, HIV, syphilis, lyme, CSF (flow cytometry and cytology), audiometry, fluorescein angiography.

ft_proposed_investigations: MRI of brain and orbits with gadolinium (including posterior fossa sequences)
MRI of cervical spine with gadolinium
MR angiography of head and neck (including vertebral arteries)
Lumbar puncture with CSF cell count, protein, glucose, oligoclonal bands and IgG index
Ophthalmology assessment with dilated fundus examination and optical coherence tomography
CT chest with contrast to evaluate left lung-base airspace disease and exclude malignancy
Onconeural antibody panel (e.g. anti-Yo, anti-Hu, anti-Ri, anti-Tr)

Management.report_string:
--- Management ---
Steroids: Not appropriate to suggest treatment at this time.
  
Correctly identified the following:

- Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (CXR: Airspace disease with air bronchograms left lung base.).
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Presenting complaint not specified, so no indication whether this is a new or an old deficit.

DMTs: Appropriate to consider but delay treatment.
  
Correctly identified the following:

- Need confirmation of MS diagnosis.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (CXR: Airspace disease with air bronchograms left lung base.).

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Inpatient admission with neuro-observations, falls precautions and physiotherapy-led gait training
reasons: Marked gait ataxia and unilateral limb dysmetria place the patient at high risk of falls and injury
Inpatient monitoring allows early detection of neurological deterioration while investigations are completed

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Optimisation of diabetes control and institution of foot-care measures
reasons: Distal large-fibre sensory loss is consistent with diabetic neuropathy and improved glycaemic control can slow progression
Structured foot care reduces risk of ulceration and infection in the setting of reduced sensation

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Empiric antibiotic therapy for suspected left lower-lobe pneumonia, tailored to local guidelines
reasons: Chest X-ray shows airspace disease with air bronchograms at the left lung base, compatible with consolidation
Early treatment is advisable in a diabetic patient to prevent respiratory and systemic deterioration

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone for a suspected multiple sclerosis relapse
reasons: Should only be started after MRI confirms an acute demyelinating lesion involving the cerebellum or brainstem
Active infection and alternative structural diagnoses must be excluded before initiating high-dose steroids

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Initiation of long-term disease-modifying therapy for multiple sclerosis
reasons: Requires a definite diagnosis of multiple sclerosis based on McDonald criteria
Choice of agent needs multidisciplinary discussion and detailed counselling about benefits and risks

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin for secondary prevention if imaging confirms cerebellar ischaemic stroke
reasons: Not indicated until ischaemic stroke is proven and haemorrhage is excluded on neuroimaging
Dose and duration should follow stroke guidelines and be individualised based on vascular risk

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Neurosurgical and oncology referral for resection or radiotherapy if a cerebellar mass lesion is identified
reasons: Definitive management depends on MRI characterisation of any mass lesion
Intervention is only appropriate once tumour type, size and resectability are defined

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Ophthalmology referral for assessment and management of profound left visual loss
reasons: Left eye has no perception of light with a relative afferent pupillary defect, requiring urgent structural evaluation
Early ophthalmic input allows optimisation of diabetic retinopathy or optic neuropathy management and provision of low-vision support

ft_plan.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone for a suspected multiple sclerosis relapse
reasons: Should only be started after MRI confirms an acute demyelinating lesion involving the cerebellum or brainstem
Active infection and alternative structural diagnoses must be excluded before initiating high-dose steroids

missing_information: Presenting complaint not specified, so no indication whether this is a new or an old deficit.
contraindications: Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (CXR: Airspace disease with air bronchograms left lung base.).
